newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft buying stake in cable TV operator.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft buying stake in cable TV operator.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. said Monday it was going into the cable television business with a $1 billion investment in Philadelphia's Comcast Corp. , one of the biggest U.S. cable operators.
Microsoft will buy 24.6 million shares of Comcast Class A special common stock for $500 million, and $500 million of a new issue of Comcast Series B convertible preferred stock.

"Our vision connecting the world of PCs and TVs has long included advanced broadband capabilities to deliver video, data and interactivity to the home," Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates said in a press release. "Comcast's integrated approach to cable distribution, programming and telecommunications complements that vision of linking PC and TV."

Comcast President Brian Roberts said, "In addition to a significant cash infusion, this investment gives us access to Microsoft's expertise, which will help us facilitate the deployment of high bandwidth applications and lead to more sophisticated services."

The deal gives Microsoft an avenue into the control and distribution of television programming. Also, the New York Times said Microsoft appeared interested in using Comcast's distribution pipeline for Microsoft Network.

The Comcast Class B shares will have a 5.25 percent pay-in-kind dividend and will be initially convertible into 21.2 million shares, which equals an initial conversion price of $23.54 per share, the company said. The conversion price will increase proportionately to the amount of accrued dividends.
The deal is expected to close this month.
